name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

key_work.brief_description: Deborah Kelly’s The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopaedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies.

start.title: Princess Mononoke
start.creator_credit: Toshio Suzuki, Nippon Television Network Corporation and Neil Gaiman
start.brief_description: Ashitaka, a prince of the disappearing Emishi people, is cursed by a demonized boar god and must journey to the west to find a cure. Along the way, he encounters San, a young human woman fighting to protect the forest, and Lady Eboshi, who is trying to destroy it. Ashitaka must find a way to bring balance to this conflict.

constellations_other.description: Waves of animators have been inspired by the style of previous animators to help tell their own stories.

links.description: In Princess Mononoke, demonic boars terrorise human interlopers. Fans have likened the characters to aggressive, radioactive boars spotted around Fukushima, Japan since the 2011 tsunami/earthquake caused a nuclear disaster at Daichi power plant, drawing a parallel between the film’s message and real-world concerns.

end.title: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami
end.brief_description: How the media produces news changed dramatically when bystanders captured the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami on handheld cameras. After obtaining the footage, news outlets circulated it around the globe. Today, social media allows spectators to share footage and images of world events instantly.

constellations_primary.name: Representing disasters
constellations_primary.description: The devastating Indian Ocean tsunami was captured by many people on personal devices and home cameras, with the footage broadcast to the world. The event also inspired feature films that are part of a long tradition of disaster films, which often push the boundaries of VFX.

links.description: Seven years before the devastating 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami, another earthquake with a magnitude over 9 on the Richter scale was recorded and led to the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami and earthquake. News footage of the disaster was widely captured on amateur video and used by media outlets to document the disaster.

links.description: During the making of Gods of Tiny Things, Kelly and her collaborators watched Hayao Miyazaki’s Princess Mononoke for inspiration. Both works deal with the environmental destruction brought by humans on the natural landscape and feature fantastical characters.

end.title: Webwurld
end.credit_line:
Jess Johnson and Simon Ward

Single-channel video work

ACMI Collection
end.headline_credit: Aotearoa / New Zealand and United States, 2017
end.material_description: Soundtrack by Andrew Clarke. video, colour and audio
end.brief_description: Webwurld appears like fragments of a dream, mesmerising its viewers with a cosmic, otherworldly dimension that seems to stretch out in every direction.

constellations_primary.name: Webwurlds
constellations_primary.description: Jess Johnson and Simon Ward's work is inspired by science fiction and fantasy. Johnson's hand-drawn illustrations are heavily detailed with geometric patterns and incorporate anthropomorphic characters amongst architectural environments in immersive other worlds.

constellations_other.name: From queer period romances to surrealistic worlds
constellations_other.description: Explore the interconnections between queer period dramas, through to sci-fi and surrealistic worlds.

links.description: Both Deborah Kelly, and Jess Johnson and Simon Ward create immersive, speculative worlds in their works. Gods of Tiny Things sees Kelly create beautiful and grotesque creatures who create a symbology for a precarious world, while Johnson and Ward’s practice meshes cultural symbology, humanoid clones and messianic figures to question the future.

links.description: The Clone Wars character Ahsoka Tano was directly inspired by San from Princess Mononoke, according to Clone Wars creator Dave Filoni. Ahoska moves like San, has an affinity with wolf-like creatures, is fiercely independent and is spiritually connected to nature.
